ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Development and writing of a full length thesis paper, giving/receiving constructive feedback on writing, research and methodology techniques.

I would say this course was more insight than anything. It was helpful in hearing how other students' theses were going, and getting advice for my own process. I wouldn't say that I learned much about the subject matter of American Studies, but it was helpful in honing strategies for researching, outlining, and writing a thesis.
I learned how to structure and plan a long-term piece of academic research in American Studies.
How to write, support for my thesis
Some basic stuff about research, library skills, writing skills, more tips on tricks on citations, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The small group is great in facilitating discussion and actually getting a lot of one-on-one help. Not too many weaknesses. I would just say more productive writing time on our own away from class.

It is useful to have a place for seniors in the major to collaborate and commiserate about their theses, but the course itself often feels less productive than it could be. I think everything we accomplished in first semester could have been done with very brief check-ins every week. The short writing assignments often felt distracting from what I was actually working on. I'm doing a bit of an unorthodox project, so I'm fully ready to believe it's more useful for more traditional students. And Salonee is lovely! But the checking in felt more productive than any actual assigned work for the colloquium.
The course is helpful for senior American Studies majors because it is loosely structured, allowing students to discuss the issues most relevant to their theses.  I have no improvements to propose.

I think the timeline of the AMST intensive thesis gets off to a pretty rollicking start. Every step is due too early, especially the prospectus and lit review. I found myself doing perfunctory tasks badly in order to focus on the actual stuff I had to do. I also think it could be tailored to different projects rather than just the 60 page academic paper. The creative prospect people really need their own class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If they want to write a thesis, it's required! If the department can make it slightly less of a commitment, that would be ideal. But I would recommend writing a thesis, and so I would necessarily recommend this course!
I would recommend this course to American Studies majors. Taking ownership over an independent thesis is an invigorating way to spend senior year.
Yes, I mean they have to take it if they want to do an intensive project.
